subject: Re: Theories Usability
msgSnippet: Absolutely.  It is particularly important since the array of values is determined programatically.  As I add new instances of entities that have to be tested,
messageBody:
Absolutely. It is particularly important since the array of values is determined programatically. As I add new instances of entities that have to be tested, that will affect the order of the data points.

Additionally, what may be just as useful, or even more useful is for the Theories test runner to decorate the assertion failure message. For example: the parameter values would be prepended to the failure message (even when the message has no value).



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> Up at the top is the bit that's supposed to be helpful: it's the 16th
> element of the collectEntityAttributes array that's failing. I'll bet
> that would be much more helpful if it printed the value, rather than
> the location in the array. What do you think?
>
> David
>
> On Mon, Feb 8, 2010 at 4:10 PM, Berin <berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
> > I dug out my work laptop.  Attached is the stacktrace provided by Eclipse:
> >
> >
> > org.junit.experimental.theories.internal.ParameterizedAssertionError: examineClass(collectEntityAttributes[15])
> >        at

<snip/>
